Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
But I heard him exclaim, ere he drove out of sight
“Happy Christmas to all, and to all a good night!”

Name: Gary
Content: absolutely loving the Bristol Museum Christmas tweets!!!!

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
He sprang to his sleigh, to his team gave a whistle,
And away they all flew like the down of a thistle.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
And laying his finger aside of his nose,
And giving a nod, up the chimney he rose;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
He spoke not a word, but went straight to his work,
And filled all the stockings; then turned with a jerk,

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
A wink of his eye and a twist of his head
Soon gave me to know I had nothing to dread;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
He was chubby and plump, a right jolly old elf,
And I laughed when I saw him, in spite of myself;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
He had a broad face and a little round belly
That shook when he laughed, like a bowl full of jelly.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
The stump of a pipe he held tight in his teeth,
And the smoke, it encircled his head like a wreath;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
His droll little mouth was drawn up like a bow,
And the beard on his chin was as white as the snow;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
His eyes—how they twinkled! his dimples how merry!  
His cheeks were like roses, his nose like a cherry!

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
A bundle of Toys he had flung on his back,
And he looked like a pedler just opening his pack.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
He was dressed all in fur, from his head to his foot,  
And his clothes were all tarnished with ashes and soot;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
As I drew in my head, and was turning around,  
Down the chimney St. Nicholas came with a bound.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
- And then, in a twinkling, I heard on the roof  
The prancing and pawing of each little hoof.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
So up to the house-top the coursers they flew,  
With the sleigh full of Toys, and St. Nicholas too.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
As dry leaves that before the wild hurricane fly,
When they meet with an obstacle, mount to the sky;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
To the top of the porch! to the top of the wall!  
Now dash away! dash away! dash away all!”

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
“Now, Dasher! now, Dancer! now, Prancer and Vixen!  
On, Comet! on, Cupid! on, Donder and Blitzen!

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
More rapid than eagles his coursers they came,  
And he whistled, and shouted, and called them by name;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
With a little old driver, so lively and quick,  
I knew in a moment it must be St. Nick.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
When, what to my wondering eyes should appear,
But a miniature sleigh, and eight tiny reindeer,

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
The moon on the breast of the new-fallen snow  
Gave the lustre of mid-day to objects below,

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
Away to the window I flew like a flash,  
Tore open the shutters and threw up the sash.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
When out on the lawn there arose such a clatter,  
I sprang from the bed to see what was the matter.

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
And mamma in her ’kerchief, and I in my cap,  
Had just settled our brains for a long winter’s nap,

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
The children were nestled all snug in their beds,
While visions of sugar-plums danced in their heads;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
The stockings were hung by the chimney with care,  
In hopes that St. Nicholas soon would be there;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content:
‘Twas the night before Christmas, when all through the house  
Not a creature was stirring, not even a mouse;

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: We really appreciate your feedback and hope this has gone some way to address your concerns. Please feel free to get in touch with us directly if you have any further questions: museumretail@bristol.gov.uk (3/3)

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: We discuss this issue a lot & completely agree that shop sections shouldn’t be gendered. It was originally set up this way because lots of people search for terms such as ‘gifts for him’ and our website is built on user need (SEO). (2/3)

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: Thanks for the feedback. We don’t want to imply that certain subjects or products are for certain genders. Since we’re always open to doing things differently, we’re going to change the layout of the website. (1/3)

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: From our #empirecollection a skirt worn by women on Kitava, one of the Trobriand Islands in the Pacific Ocean. A great deal of skill would have gone into making this colourful, multi-layered piece made from plant fibre and worn for dances and on ceremonial occasions.

Content: We're looking at how discussion of Empire can permeate many of the permanent displays, using the collections to address issues and talk about the role of Empire in both the world’s and the museum’s histories. Hope that helps. (2 of 2) ^ad

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: We're currently checking & better cataloguing & storing the collection, whilst considering how to use it in the future.  We may not have a dedicated Empire & Commonwealth gallery in the future but we do plan to have a series of temporary exhibitions in Bristol. (1 of 2) ^ad

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: We have lots of interesting textiles in our #empirecollection. The patterns on these examples from Tonga and Fiji are usually hand painted or stencilled onto barkcloth (called ngatu and masi repectively) but here traditional patterns have been commercially printed onto cotton.^fd

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: How sweet!  That made my day! This window is on the first floor of  where I have my lunch. It can only be seen by the  public from outside of the building but still looks very beautiful. If you want to see it from the inside become a volunteer! 6/6 #PlacementStudent

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: Curious about what they are doing? They are working . I went there with  International Training Programme students  - we really enjoyed the traditional glassblowing. This year is the first year ITP students have been. 5/6 #PlacementStudent

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: Don’t be freaked out! It’s not human hair or a dead body! The main character in this picture is my glove. Even though they are fine quality gloves they still broke and became dirty after one day's object handling. How many I used showed how hard I worked 4/6 #PlacementStudent

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: That’s a feather fan, SEE even after 70 years it is still fabulous! We take pictures of objects as part of my daily work but this picture was just for fun LOL. Sometimes I needed to stand on steps to have a better view and I felt like a giant! 3/6 #PlacementStudent

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: That’s me,  wearing a face mask. I was working with my colleagues on a beautiful but mouldy feather fan. If you look carefully you can see a pair of animal horns on the shelf - when you walk through the shelves you may need a light to give you more courage 2/6 #PlacementStudent

Content: Today and tomorrow in the #MakeSpace: Join multi-disciplinary fine artist @AmandaJChambers as she demonstrates the Japanese ceramics technique of ‘throwing from the hump’ and the production of miniature tea pots. https://bristolmuseums.org.uk/bristol-museum-and-art-gallery/whats-on/the-make-space-programme/…

Content: Did you know that Bristol used to be 10 minutes, 22.3 seconds behind London? Our scientific compensation clock has an extra hand which shows 'Bristol time' as well as GMT. The clock is wound weekly but still manages to run slightly behind time. #differenceMW #MuseumWeek

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: Bristol author Amelia Edwards arrived in Egypt in December 1873. She spent the next 4 months sailing the river Nile visiting ancient sites - this journey would change her life forever. Discover more about this extraordinary woman at our lunchtime talk Thursday 1:15pm ^lt

Content: On this day in 1806 Admiral Horatio Lord Nelson received a state funeral and was interred in St Paul's Cathedral - we have this image of his tomb by the printmaker Annie Williams in our collection (Date: 1900/1910). Find it here: https://bristolmuseums.org.uk/collections/  ^jg

Name: Bristol Museum & Art Gallery
Content: The Dutch artist Lawrence Alma-Tadema was born on this day in 1836. His "Unconscious Rivals" have come back from loan just in time to celebrate and are now back on display in Gallery 6. They also grace the cover of our new guide to the art collections - available in the shop. ^jg
